conclusion: To determine the trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval from 0 to \( t_2 \), we need to analyze the velocity-time (v-t) graph for object B.
The v-t graph shows the velocity of object B as a function of time.
The slope of the v-t graph at any point represents the acceleration of the object at that instant.
At \( t = 0 \), the velocity of object B is at its maximum.
As time progresses from 0 to \( t_1 \), the velocity decreases, indicating a negative slope.
At \( t = t_1 \), the velocity reaches a minimum (possibly zero or a negative value).
From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), the velocity increases, indicating a positive slope.

premise: The negative slope from 0 to \( t_1 \) indicates that the acceleration is negative (deceleration).
conclusion: From 0 to \( t_1 \), the acceleration is negative.

premise: The positive slope from \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \) indicates that the acceleration is positive (acceleration).
conclusion: From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), the acceleration is positive.

premise: From 0 to \( t_1 \), the acceleration is negative and decreasing (becoming more negative).
conclusion: From 0 to \( t_1 \), the acceleration decreases.

premise: At \( t_1 \), the acceleration is at its most negative (minimum).
conclusion: At \( t_1 \), the acceleration reaches its minimum.

premise: From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), the acceleration becomes positive and increases.
conclusion: From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), the acceleration increases.

premise: The trend of the acceleration of object B during the time interval from 0 to \( t_2 \) is as follows: It starts negative and decreases (becomes more negative) until \( t_1 \). At \( t_1 \), it reaches its minimum (most negative). From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), it becomes positive and increases.
conclusion: The acceleration of B first decreases and then increases.
